11: Coordinates for an area in deep space.
14: Landing site is planet-side wilderness, far from human habitation, or on an uninhabited world.
21: A mining facility, far from a colony or starport.
31: Spaceport on an asteroid or moon, or a landing field near a larger settlement.
34: The surface of an asteroid or a small moon. Vacuum or dangerous atmosphere.
44: The busy hub of all interstellar traffic and commerce.
51: A small colony with only a few hundred inhabitants.
54: A busy colony with several thousand people and a thriving, local industry.
61: A starship in orbit, awaiting your arrival.
64: A small outpost, usually planetside. An outpost is commonly just a single complex with a specific function;corporate, military or scientific.

11: Propylene, acetylene, propane, ethyl-formate, chlorofluorocarbon, ammonia, carbon monoxide, ethylene oxide, hydrogen chloride, sulfur dioxide, sulfur hexafluoride.
13: Gold, platinum, palladium, silver, tungsten, copper, iron, etc.
15: Humans in stasis, ready to begin a colonization project.
21: Exotic alien tree products destined for Earth.
22: Water, water ice or some other rare frozen solution.
23: Aluminium Chloride, Aluminium Sulfate, Calcium Acetate, Monosodium Phosphate, Ferric Sulphate, Sodium Hydroxide, Hydrochloric Acid, Sodium Aluminate, Polyaluminium Chloride, Ferrous Chloride, Borate, Potassium Acetate etc.
24: Multi-nutrient fertilizer compounds made up of nitrogen, potassium and/or phosphate.
25: Crude oil, or liquid petroleum by-products.
31: Bulk foods such as chickpeas, soybeans and other legumes, grains (corn, barley, rice, wheat) or refined versions thereof.
33: Bauxite (aluminum), galena (lead), pentlandite (nickel), gold-quartz, cassiterite (tin), malachite (copper), magnetite (iron), platinum-bearing sand, trimonite (tungsten).
41: Vaccines, medicines, disinfectants, surgical gear, scanning machines, hospital beds.
42: Different makes and types, for suits, refineries, vehicles, power stations, hospitals, prospecting gear, factories, atmospheric processors, weaponry or life support systems.
44: Modules, features, parts for/from dismantled ships.
46: Space suits for delivery to the colonies.
51: Wind turbines, power station generator, space station hull frame, solar panel assembly, drilling machinery, ore processing mill or furnace.
52: Diggers, tractors, quad-tracks, all-terrain vehicles, power loaders.
53: Firearms, ammunition and armor for the colonies or remote stations.
55: Processed uranium cakes or uranium dioxide powder, or fusion plant fuel pellets such as deuterium, tritium, protium or helium-3.
61: Beams, modules, airlocks, outer shells, roofing material, etc.
63: Feed concentrates containing grains, high-protein oil meals and byproducts of sugar beet and sugarcane processing.
64: Cattle in stasis, ready for rearing on an off-world colony.
66: Shuttle, or escape/cargo pod requiring investigation and study.

11: The destination is placed under quarantine or an embargo.
14: The ship’s computer brings the ship out of hyperspace early, and then wakes the crew. What’s the story?
21: A military starship sends over a small search party for a “routine” ICC and customs check. Should the PCs be worried?
31: There is a delay in lift-off/undocking; perhaps fuel for the reaction drives or coolant cannot be pumped aboard. There may be a strike, an administrative hold-up or loading equipment may have broken down.
34: A critical part (drive pump, plasma coil, coolant pump, water recycler, gravity compensator control unit, sensor gimbal motor, etc.) requires replacement before it fails, requiring most of the crew’s participation.
44: Problems at the destination mean they aren’t ready to accept the cargo. Can the crew help speed things along?
54: There is a serious problem with the cargo, either moving, leaking, over-heating or catching fire.
61: A small piece of wreckage is spotted on the sensor scope; a cargo container, escape pod, frozen corpse, part of a starship—smashed or blown off, etc.
